Today is not another day for the japanese. Jus like the hiroshima and nagasaki, this day (11.3.11) marks a part in the history. It was a fateful day !!! :( Earth quake and tsunami's shaking japan one after the other. 
Till now a death rate of 400 have been reported and the videos of the floating cars and buildings will definetely add on to the death rates. T?hoku region Pacific Ocean offshore earthquake was an 8.9-magnitude megathrust earthquake that created tsunami waves of up to 10 metres (33 ft). The earthquake caused buildings in the Japanese capital of Tokyo to shake. Several fires have been reported in Tokyo and other parts of the country including a large oil refinery fire in Chiba Prefecture.

In a country like Japan who are much know for their hardworking roots and who are the frontiers in science and technology " what happened to an Early warning System??? "

Let's pray for the rested souls !!

Links: http://ptwc.weather.gov/
          http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Sendai_earthquake_and_tsunami

Microsoft appears to be playing catch-up, The concept is definitely interesting as it provides a way to rapidly generate road data over the entire globe without need of manual tracing. This really does seem to be an example of Microsoft trying an innovative application of technology and, while the image pattern recognition algorithms behind this service are certainly not new. Essentially, given the latitude and longitude coordinates of a bounding box, and two points that lie somewhere on a road in that area, the service attempts to use Bing Maps’ aerial imagery dataset to automatically identify the set of points following the route of that road (and, optionally, other roads that connect to it).  With a combination of automatic, approximate feature identification, and manual correction and correlation against Bing Maps aerial imagery, we could very quickly see a large amount of routing data being made available in countries that at the moment have no road network information.




Check this video
Further info:  http://magicshop.cloudapp.net/ , bingmaps

Happy to hear about ur views !! :)

Another Interesting blogroll that excited me. Just sharing few info abt it..!! :)

         German scientists have developed a car that can be used without the need driven. driver's brain would determine the direction and the vehicle was moving as desired. The driver was wearing a special headset - originally designed for video games - which have sensors and connected to the vehicle electronic devices wirelessly. Brain driver only needs to "think" like "turn left", "turn right" and added speed. Equipment named BrainDriver worked with to get input from a variety of video cameras in vehicles, radars and sensors. The supply of such data can provide 3-dimensional views of the surrounding cars. Special headset consists of 16 sensors that charge capture the brain electromagnetic signals. Computer translated the signal. In the pilot, the driver can steer left or right turning vehicles although there is little lag between the time you give the command to move the vehicle. In the 2nd test, the vehicle was "trained" to recognize the turn left, turn right, plus the gas and brake pressure. The project was conducted by a team AutoNOMOS, one unit of the Artificial Intelligence Group, which owned Freie Universität in Berlin.The researchers suggested their work a new concept and "still far from the engine control technology with the brain.

Get ready to see the Moon in a bigger and better picture on 19 march. Super full moon will be rising near the horizons.

A perigee full Moon brings with it extra-high "perigean tides," but this is nothing to worry about, according to NOAA. In most places, lunar gravity at perigee pulls tide waters only a few centimeters (an inch or so) higher than usual. Local geography can amplify the effect to about 15 centimeters (six inches)--not exactly a great flood.

Earth goes around the sun once a year where Saturn goes around the sun once about every 30 years.
That makes April and May of 2011 the best months for seeing this most amazing and beautiful of planets.

Saturn reaches opposition on April 4. This is when Saturn and the sun are on opposite sides of the sky, as seen from Earth. At opposition the planet rises at sunset and sets at sunrise. It's also physically closest to the Earth in its orbit, so it appears larger and brighter. In fact, this month it's the only bright planet you'll see at night. For the last two years, most people have been disappointed because Saturn's famous rings have been "edge on" to Earth. Saturn’s rings are tilted towards a particular point in the sky so that as Saturn travels in its orbit around the sun, sometimes the rings are presented towards us and at other times they disappear when the Earth is in the same plane as the rings. The Cassini spacecraft has been studying the Saturn system for almost seven years, sending back data and amazing images of the rings, icy moons, Saturn's magnetosphere, Titan and Saturn itself.




 Source: http://solarsystem.jpl.nasa.gov/
             http://www.space.com/11262-saturn-skywatching-tips-evening-sky.html

Clusters of yellow lights on the Indo-Gangetic Plain reveal numerous cities large and small in this astronaut photograph of northern India and northern Pakistan. Of the hundreds of clusters, the largest are the capital cities of Islamabad, Pakistan, and New Delhi, India. (For scale, these metropolitan areas are approximately 700 kilometers or 435 miles apart.) The lines of major highways connecting the cities also stand out. More subtle, but still visible at night, are the general outlines of the towering and partly cloud-covered Himalayas to the north (image left).
A striking feature is the line of lights, with a distinctly orange hue, snaking across the center of the image. It appears to be more continuous and brighter than most highways in the view. This is the fenced and floodlit border zone between India and Pakistan. The fence is designed to discourage smuggling and arms trafficking. A similar fenced zone separates India’s eastern border from Bangladesh (not visible).


 Source:http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov

This image was taken with a 16 mm lens, which provides the wide field of view, as the International Space Station (ISS) was tracking towards the southeast across India. The ISS crew took the image as part of a continuous series of frames, each with a one-second exposure time to maximize light collection. Unfortunately, this also causes blurring of some ground features.
The distinct, bright zone above the horizon (visible at image top) is airglow, a phenomena caused by excitation of atoms and molecules high in the atmosphere (above 80 kilometers, or 50 miles altitude) by ultraviolet radiation from the Sun. Part of the ISS Permanent Multipurpose Module and a solar panel array are visible at image right.

Indeed it's better to monitor the climate change from ground based observations too in order to validate the Space observation. In this note "Mobotix" a German company has setup a Web cam in Kala Patthar for monitoring. 

A look of setting up the Webcam


Mobotix, creators of high-res video systems, set a record for the world’s highest webcam streaming real time video and pictures of Everest from nearby Kala Patthar. The camera is recording images of the 8.848m tall Mount Everest and is part of a project to calculate the exact height of the mountain. The image is updated every five minutes and only operates during daylight hours – 6am to 6pm Nepal time.


The camera is part of the Everest Share 2011 research project which has been launched to capture data and weather information as well as determine the exact height  of the mountain using cutting-edge technology. In the process the Mobotix camera being used set a new world record as the highest webcam atop Kala Patthar which is 5,675m high.

The solar powered Mobotix M12 camera is robust and flexible to handle the harsh environment which includes temperatures that can drop to minus 30 degrees Celsius.
 
You can see the live images from the Mount Everest webcam here.
